aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Information for Rio Verde, Arizona
The accident occurred in Rio Verde, Arizona.
The accident occurred on October 12, 2013.
The accident occurred at 12:30 Local time.
The aircraft involved was an AVIAT AIRCRAFT INC A-1C-180.
The aircraft registration was N40WY.
The defining event was loss of control on ground.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was WPR14CA015.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were 2 occupants in the aircraft.
No injuries occurred in the accident.
The pilot reported that the airplane veered to the left of centerline during the takeoff roll.
The takeoff roll occurred on a dirt airstrip.
The dirt airstrip was rutted and rough.
The dirt airstrip was narrow.
The pilot tried to correct back to the right.
The left wing contacted brush on the side of the airstrip.
The airplane was pulled around after contacting the brush.
The left wing contacted the surface.
Both wings were substantially damaged.
The fuselage was substantially damaged.
The pilot reported no preimpact mechanical malfunctions with the airplane.
The pilot reported no preimpact mechanical failures with the airplane.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the pilot's failure to maintain directional control during the takeoff roll.
The takeoff roll occurred on a rough and rutted surface.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Rio Verde, Arizona

## Date & Time: 
October 12, 2013, 12:30 Local

## Aircraft:
AVIAT AIRCRAFT INC A-1C-180

## Defining Event:
Loss of control on ground

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
WPR14CA015

## Registration:
N40WY

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 None

## Analysis

The pilot reported that during the takeoff roll on a dirt airstrip that was rutted and rough, the airplane veered to the left of centerline. The pilot tried to correct back to the right, however the left wing contacted brush on the side of the narrow airstrip. The airplane was subsequently pulled around and the left wing contacted the surface. Both wings and the fuselage were substantially damaged. The pilot reported no preimpact mechanical malfunctions or failures with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be: The pilot's failure to maintain directional control during the takeoff roll on a rough and rutted surface.

---
